data.text: @grevory @outsidetheboxNL @CBCNL I'm not for banning smoking, just think there's an easier case to be made for it than mandating vaxs. Yes, covid is contagious. I understand that makes it different from smoking and exercise. If the vaccines prevented spread there would be a stronger argument for mandates.

@grevory @outsidetheboxNL @CBCNL I have never made a statement like that. Obvs if 90% of the pop is vaxd, the majority of ppl in hospital can be vaxd and the vax still be effective. I understand that simple math. It is my opinion that they are not nearly effective enough to mandate.

@dawe_andrew @outsidetheboxNL @CBCNL And I'm with you. Let's ban smoking. Let's incentivize better health.

But Covid is contagious, which is why you have seen more immediate action to contain it.

@dawe_andrew @outsidetheboxNL @CBCNL While I personally support the mandates thats another discussion. You have been making statements that vaccines arent effective b/c most people in the hospital are vaccinated. That's not true. You dont need to rely on NLs numbers for extrapolation. The data is the same everywhere

@grevory @outsidetheboxNL @CBCNL Not sure there's enough information in that article to do any meaningful extrapolation like this. But even if they are preventing a lot of hospitalizations, I don't see an argument for mandates here. Imo there's an easier argument to ban smoking, mandate exercise, etc.

@HeraKitty @CBCNL Yeah, that makes sense, given the high vaccination rate. People who are elderly or have underlying conditions are still at risk of getting pretty sick. If the vaccine didn't do anything, the rate of unvaccinated hospitalizations would be closer to 4.57% of the total.

@HeraKitty @CBCNL Based on that hospitalization rate if the entire population has remained unvaccinated we could have expected over 2k hospitalizations, which would have devastated our health care system. (5% of 500k ~ 25k, 137 / 25k ~ 0.05%, 0.05% * 500k ~ 2740). Vaccinations work.
@SeanJac68772609 @CBCNL The data also shows the vaccine is likely not a major factor, age & comorbidities are. As has been since 2020. Glad they're recognizing the science, finally.
